title: 111_hr6522
content: The "End Tax Uncertainty Act of 2010" repeals certain tax relief acts, including the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. It also permanently repeals the estate and gift tax and provides permanent relief from the individual Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT). The "End Tax Uncertainty Act of 2010" repeals tax relief acts, including the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. It permanently repeals the estate and gift tax and provides permanent relief from the individual Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) exemption amount. The text outlines specified exemption amounts for different taxpayer categories, including individuals, married individuals filing separately, estates, and trusts. The term "surviving spouse" is defined, and marital status is determined according to specific sections of the Code. For paragraph (1)(A), taxpayers are categorized based on specific criteria. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 are as follows: $72,450 in 2010, $74,450 in 2011, $78,250 in 2012, $81,450 in 2013, $85,050 in 2014, $88,650 in 2015, $92,650 in 2016, and $96,550 in 2017. In 2017, the exemption amount was $96,550, which increased to $100,950 in 2018, $105,150 in 2019, and $109,950 in 2020. Taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(B) for tax purposes. The exemption amount for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 is as follows: $47,450 in 2010, $48,450 in 2011, $50,350 in 2012, $51,950 in 2013, $53,750 in 2014, $55,550 in 2015, $57,550 in 2016, and $59,500 in 2017. The exemption amount increased steadily from $59,500 in 2017 to $66,200 in 2020. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year based on the taxpayer's regular tax liability and the tax imposed for the year. Conforming amendments are made to the Adoption credit sections. Section 23(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the credit limitations for taxable years, allowing excess credits to be carried over to the following year. Additionally, paragraph (3) is redesignated as paragraph (2) in effect on December 31, 2009. Child tax credit under Section 24 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by removing paragraph (3) and adjusting references to other sections. The Internal Revenue Code is being amended to adjust various tax credits. Section 25(e)(1)(C) is updated to define the 'applicable tax limit.' Section 25B is modified by removing subsection (g) related to the savers' credit. Section 25D(c) now allows for the carryforward of unused credits. The Internal Revenue Code is being amended to adjust various tax credits, including those for plug-in electric vehicles and alternative motor vehicles. The amendments allow for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code is being amended to adjust tax credits for plug-in electric vehicles. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to the foreign tax credit and the first-time home buyer credit for the District of Columbia. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year starting after December 31, 2009. The corporate income tax rate is reduced to 25 percent, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. Personal service corporations will now be taxed at a maximum rate of 25 percent instead of 35 percent. Various sections of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to reflect this change.
